message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms indicate a possibility of a drug reaction, specifically serum sickness. The fact that the boy is currently taking antibiotics, and the appearance of the rash and joint pain after starting the medication, supports this possibility. Therefore, the most appropriate next step in management is to discontinue the antibiotic. Switching to doxycycline is not appropriate as it is also an antibiotic and may have similar effects. Prednisone may help with symptoms but the first step is to discontinue the causative agent. Allergy testing is not indicated in this case as the reaction is likely due to a drug and not an allergy.

Discontinuation of the antibiotic is the most appropriate next step in management. Prednisone and allergy testing are not appropriate management options for this scenario.

Discontinuing the antibiotics is the most appropriate next step in management. Switching to doxycycline may not help as it is also an antibiotic. Allergy testing can be considered later, but is not necessary for immediate management.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, especially the rash and joint pain along with proteinuria, suggest a possible diagnosis of acute post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis. Antibiotic treatment for pharyngitis is important to prevent complications such as rheumatic fever, but it can also cause a hypersensitivity reaction that results in acute glomerulonephritis. Discontinuing the antibiotic is the most appropriate next step in management. Switching to an alternative antibiotic, such as doxycycline, is not necessary since the pharyngitis has already been treated. Prednisone may be used if there is severe joint pain or renal impairment, but it is not an appropriate first-line treatment. Allergy testing is not indicated in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, including the rash, joint pain, and proteinuria suggest a possible diagnosis of acute post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (APSGN). Antibiotic use can sometimes cause a rash, but the presence of joint pain and proteinuria make APSGN the more likely diagnosis. Discontinuing the antibiotic is the most appropriate next step. Allergy testing and switching to doxycycline are not necessary. Prednisone should not be used for treatment of APSGN. Prompt referral to a nephrologist for further evaluation and management is recommended.

Antibiotics should be discontinued immediately as they do not alter the course of the disease. Prednisone can actually worsen the situation by delaying the healing of kidneys. Allergy testing is not helpful in this situation.
